(Class will meet synchronously on Thurs. 11:20 AM - 12:35 PM)
(This course surveys the influences and forces that shaped Western thought, society, and culture from the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the beginning of the Early Modern Era (100 - 1500 CE).  Special attention will be given to the cultural and religious diversity of medieval Europe and European involvement in the Mediterranean through the crusades, conquest, and trade. The history of Muslim-Christian relations in this region meant that contact facilitated the spread of ideas, food, technology, art, and architecture. We will study cross-cultural encounters through pilgrimage, slavery, and commercial networks that had an effect on Western European society. Other highlights of the course include monasticism, movements of religious reform, heresy, the controversy over marriage, feudal society, and peasant, university, and courtly life.)
course_description: Examines the early forms of those societies that came to dominate the European continent and explores their early expansion and influence.
